 archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, Gordon Mohr <gojomo@...> wrote:
>
> shich=
uanwuhan@... wrote:
> Re: [archive-crawler] What on earth is the different =
between seeds and 
> surts-source-file?
> > I don't understand even though =
I have read the user manual many many times.
> 
> The 'seeds' are the start=
ing URIs for the crawl. The crawler will 
> actually attempt to visit the e=
xact URIs in the seeds file. Then, 
> depending on what outlinks are discov=
ered, and what are ruled as 
> in-scope, the crawler may visit other URIs a=
s well.
> 
> The term 'seeds' is widely used for this meaning in other writ=
ing about 
> web crawling, as well.
> 
> The term 'SURT', as a special URI =
syntax useful for describing where a 
> crawler should go, is more specific=
 to Heritrix. (Other crawlers have 
> similar ideas under other names.) The=
 meaning of 'SURT' and 
> 'SURT-prefix' is covered in the manual.
> 
> If y=
ou are using scope rules based on SURT prefixes, your scope may load 
> acc=
eptable SURTs from a file. The lines in this file are read as either 
> lit=
eral SURT-prefixes, or URIs that are converted into 'implied 
> SURT-prefix=
es'. Nothing in this file forces the crawler to try visiting 
> a URI. Rath=
er, it just makes visiting some URIs allowable, *if* those 
> URIs are disc=
overed by some other path.
> 
> If starting from the default configuration =
bundled with the crawler, 
> it's rare to need to use the 'surts-source-fil=
e'. First, because that 
> configuration is already set to treat every seed=
 as also implying a 
> matching SURT-prefix, to allow the crawl to travel t=
o natural/intuitive 
> 'extensions' of the seed. And second, because if you=
 just need to add a 
> few more SURT-prefixes, you can do so using the shor=
tcut syntax of extra 
> lines in the seeds file.
> 
> For example, this see=
ds file:
> 
> =3D=3D=3Dseeds.txt=3D=3D=3D
> http://example.com/staff/~examp=
lesen
> +http://(com,example,
> =3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=
=3D
> 
> ...is equivalent to the pair of both seeds file and surts-file:
> =

> =3D=3D=3Dseeds.txt=3D=3D=3D
> http://example.com/staff/~examplesen
> =3D=
=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D
> 
> =3D=3D=3Dsurts.txt=3D=3D=3D=

> +http://(com,example,
> =3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D
> =

> In both cases, the crawler is only told to explicitly visit the exact 
>=
 URI 'http://example.com/staff/~examplesen'. However, *if* it discovers 
> =
outlink URIs anywhere in the 'example.com' domain, it will follow those 
> =
links.
> 
> Hope this helps,
> 
> - Gordon @ IA
